verses.text: Or do you not know, brothers—for I am speaking to those who know the Law—that the Law has authority over a person only as long as he lives?
verses.comment: Paul addresses those familiar with the Law, highlighting that its authority is limited to one's lifetime. The mention of 'brothers' underscores fellowship among believers.

verses.text: For a married woman is bound by law to her husband while he lives, but if her husband dies, she is released from the law of marriage.
verses.comment: Paul uses marriage as an illustration. The end of a marital bond through death points to how death frees from obligations.

verses.text: So then, if she becomes joined to another man while her husband is alive, she will be called an adulteress. But if her husband dies, she is free from that law; and if she joins another man, she is not an adulteress.
verses.comment: The analogy shows the finality of law, and freedom granted by death. It sets the stage for Paul’s explanation of our release from the Mosaic Law through Christ.

verses.text: Therefore, my brothers, you also have died to the Law through the body of Christ, so that you may belong to another—to Him who was raised from the dead—that we might bear fruit for God.
verses.comment: Through union with Christ’s death, believers are released from the Law and now belong to Christ, who brings new life. Bearing fruit implies both ethical and spiritual transformation, pointing to a sacramental reality and spiritual growth.

verses.text: For while we were in the flesh, the sinful passions aroused by the Law were at work in our bodies to bear fruit for death.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts life under the Law and the flesh with life in the Spirit. Our natural state produces death—a theme echoing original sin.

verses.text: But now we have been released from the Law, having died to that which held us captive, so that we serve in newness of Spirit and not in the oldness of the written code.
verses.comment: Emphasis on spiritual rebirth and transformation. The idea of ‘serving in the Spirit’ implies living by grace with the guidance of the Holy Spirit, anticipating deeper sacramental life.

verses.text: What then shall we say? That the Law is sin? Absolutely not! On the contrary, I would not have known sin except through the Law. For I would not have known about coveting unless the Law had said, 'You shall not covet.'
verses.comment: Paul vindicates the Law as holy. Its purpose is to reveal sin, not to create it. The Law gives clarity to moral boundaries—pointing to the need for grace.

verses.text: But sin, taking opportunity through the commandment, produced in me all kinds of covetousness. For apart from Law, sin is dead.
verses.comment: The Law reveals and even stirs up sinful desire, making us aware of our need for divine help beyond human effort.

verses.text: I was once alive apart from the Law, but when the commandment came, sin came alive and I died.
verses.comment: Paul refers to an innocence before awareness of the Law, but with knowledge comes accountability and death through sin—a spiritual reality akin to the fall in Genesis.

verses.text: And the commandment that was meant to bring life proved to bring death for me.
verses.comment: God’s holy Law reveals the impossibility of self-salvation; we need a Redeemer who fulfills the Law and conquers death.

verses.text: For sin, taking opportunity through the commandment, deceived me and through it killed me.
verses.comment: Sin’s power lies in deception, drawing on the example of Adam and Eve’s fall. The Law exposes but cannot heal; Christ is the remedy.

verses.text: So then, the Law is holy, and the commandment is holy and righteous and good.
verses.comment: Affirms the sanctity of the Law. Its ultimate purpose points beyond itself to the necessity of grace and a new covenant.

verses.text: Did that which is good then become death to me? By no means! Rather, sin, so that it might be shown to be sin, produced death in me through what is good, so that through the commandment sin might become exceedingly sinful.
verses.comment: The Law’s goodness reveals the horror of sin. Only grace can overcome this reality. The heightened awareness is meant to drive us towards redemption.

verses.text: For we know that the Law is spiritual, but I am fleshly, sold under sin.
verses.comment: Paul confesses the contrast between God's Law and human nature. Humanity requires spiritual transformation—an organic change far deeper than legal reform.

verses.text: For I do not understand my own actions. I do not do what I want, but I do what I hate.
verses.comment: Human weakness and divided will echo the effects of original sin. The need for ongoing, supernatural assistance in living virtuously is clear.

verses.text: If I do what I do not want, I agree with the Law, that it is good.
verses.comment: Our conscience affirms the goodness of God’s Law, though we struggle to keep it perfectly.

verses.text: So now it is no longer I who do it, but sin living in me.
verses.comment: Moves toward the notion of being transformed from within. This sets the stage for the doctrine of sanctification—a process beyond self-effort, rooted in deep spiritual renewal.

verses.text: For I know that nothing good dwells in me, that is, in my flesh. For I have the desire to do what is right, but not the ability to carry it out.
verses.comment: Points to human incapacity for holiness apart from divine help—a truth emphasizing the need for constant grace, prayer, and sacramental life.

verses.text: For I do not do the good I want, but the evil I do not want, that is what I keep on doing.
verses.comment: The persistence of sin despite good intentions highlights the necessity of ongoing healing—a process found in spiritual disciplines and practices handed down through the ages.

verses.text: Now if I do what I do not want, it is no longer I doing it, but sin that lives in me.
verses.comment: Echoes the brokenness of man due to original sin. Only deep, inward renewal—mediated by Christ—can restore harmony.

verses.text: So I find this law at work: although I want to do good, evil is present with me.
verses.comment: Spiritual conflict is universal. The reality points to a need for ongoing purification in our walk with Christ.

verses.text: For I delight in the law of God in my inner being,
verses.comment: The image of ‘inner being’ points toward deeper transformation, not mere outward compliance.

verses.text: but I see another law in my members, waging war against the law of my mind and making me captive to the law of sin that is in my members.
verses.comment: Highlights the ongoing struggle and the need for both spiritual and practical remedies to overcome sin—pointing to the importance of a structured spiritual life.

verses.text: Wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from this body of death?
verses.comment: Paul’s outcry reveals the depth of need for salvation. It is not merely theoretical but calls for specific means of deliverance promised by God.

verses.text: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, I myself serve the law of God with my mind, but with my flesh I serve the law of sin.
verses.comment: Victory comes only through Christ—who offers not only forgiveness but real and ongoing victory over sin. The spiritual dimension of Christian life is united with physical transformation, anticipating new life in Christ both now and in glory.
